chunks.episode_title: Mars_ Mysteries of the Red Planet
chunks.chunk_text: This is a download from BBC Learning English. To find out more, visit our website.

chunks.episode_title: Mars_ Mysteries of the Red Planet
chunks.chunk_text: But human interest in Mars goes back much earlier. Ancient civilisations like the Maya of Central America

chunks.episode_title: Mars_ Mysteries of the Red Planet
chunks.chunk_text: preserved the planet's colour and recorded its movements, just like modern astronomers – scientists who study the universe and the stars, planets and suns within it. Yet, despite this, many questions remain unanswered. What caused the marks and scars on the planet's surface? And the biggest question of all – is there life on Mars? But before we go on, I have another question which needs answering, Sam. The ancient Romans were also interested in Mars. They even considered

chunks.episode_title: Mars_ Mysteries of the Red Planet
chunks.chunk_text: the red planet to be a god. But god of what? Was Mars the Roman god of a, love, b, fire or c, war? Well, Mars is the red planet, so I guess the answer is b, the Roman god of fire? OK, Sam. We'll find out the answer at the end of the programme.

chunks.episode_title: Mars_ Mysteries of the Red Planet
chunks.chunk_text: But where does Mars' characteristic colour come from? Someone who can answer that is Dr Michael Maier. As lead scientist on NASA's Mars Exploration Programme, he spent years observing and recording the red planet. Listen to Dr Maier in conversation with BBC World Service programme The Forum. Try to hear the explanation he gives for Mars' unusual colour.

chunks.episode_title: Mars_ Mysteries of the Red Planet
chunks.chunk_text: The interesting thing about Mars is that it's red, so you can see it and identify it. It looks red because of rust, iron oxide on the surface, which is red. And interestingly, that look can change. And we saw that in 2018 when there was a global dust storm. Mars, instead of looking red, looked a little orange. And it's that, you know, that changing of colour might have made the civilizations watching Mars

chunks.episode_title: Mars_ Mysteries of the Red Planet
chunks.chunk_text: maybe uneasy to see something immutable in our night sky changing colours. Dr Maier calls Mars' red colour distinctive, easy to recognise because it's different from everything else. But did you hear why it's red in the first place, Sam? Yes, it's red because of rust, a reddish chemical substance called iron oxide that occurs when metals react with water and air.

chunks.episode_title: Mars_ Mysteries of the Red Planet
chunks.chunk_text: The colour of this rust can change slightly from red to brown to orange. And Dr Maier thinks these changing colours may have worried ancient astronomers who believed Mars was immutable or never changing. Unlike ancient civilizations, modern astronomers have sent satellites to land on Mars and explore its surface. And although no human has set foot on the red planet so far, we know a lot about conditions there. So, in the words of David Bowie,

chunks.episode_title: Mars_ Mysteries of the Red Planet
chunks.chunk_text: they're life on Mars. Well, that all depends on finding water. Water is life. And as Dr Maier told BBC World Service's The Forum, with water, anything is possible. And from all that we have learned from astrobiology, life is amazingly adaptable, but it still needs water. So that's why water is the key. So finding liquid water on Mars, whether or not it's now or whether or not it's in the past,

chunks.episode_title: Mars_ Mysteries of the Red Planet
chunks.chunk_text: tells you that you potentially have a habitable environment, someplace that could support life and perhaps even Martian life. Dr Maier says that life is amazingly adaptable, able to change in order to survive in new situations.

chunks.episode_title: Mars_ Mysteries of the Red Planet
chunks.chunk_text: And who knows how long it could be before we see a human on Mars? And who knows what they'd find there? Tiny worms? Little green men? Or maybe a Roman god? Yes. In your quiz question, you asked what Mars was the Roman god of? And I guess B, the Roman god of fire? Which was the wrong answer, I'm afraid. In fact, the Romans considered Mars their god of war and sacrificed wild animals to him, such as wolves, bears and, strangely,

chunks.episode_title: Mars_ Mysteries of the Red Planet
chunks.chunk_text: woodpeckers. OK, Neil, let's recap the vocabulary from this programme on the red planet, Mars, starting with...

chunks.episode_title: Mars_ Mysteries of the Red Planet
chunks.chunk_text: Something which is adaptable can easily change to deal with new circumstances. And finally, habitable means good enough to live in. That's all we have time for. Bye for now. Goodbye.
